title: Charminar
summary: The Charminar, meaning 'four minarets,' is a historical monument built in 1591 in Hyderabad, Telangana, India. It serves as an iconic symbol of Hyderabad and is officially incorporated into the emblem of Telangana. The structure houses a mosque on its top floor and is renowned for its surrounding bustling local markets, making it a highly frequented tourist destination. It also hosts major festival celebrations, notably Eid, due to its proximity to the Makkah Masjid. Located on the east bank of the Musi River, the Charminar is listed as an archaeological and architectural treasure by the Archaeological Survey of India, and its name reflects its distinctive four ornate minarets supported by grand arches.
key_points: Constructed in 1591, the Charminar is a symbol of Hyderabad and is incorporated into the emblem of Telangana.
It features a mosque on its top floor that has been in use for over 425 years.
The monument is a popular tourist attraction, surrounded by busy local markets and serving as a site for festival celebrations like Eid-ul-adha and Eid al-Fitr.
It is officially listed as an archaeological and architectural treasure by the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI).
The name 'Charminar' translates to 'Four Pillars' in Urdu, referring to its four ornate minarets and grand supporting arches.
timeline: 1591: Constructed by Muhammad Quli Qutb Shah after shifting the capital to Hyderabad.
1591 (theory): Built to commemorate the eradication of a widespread plague.
1591 (theory): Erected to mark the beginning of the second Islamic millennium year (1000 AH), as noted by Jean de Thévenot.
17th Century: Documented by French traveller Jean de Thévenot, complementing available Persian texts.
Present: Maintained as an archaeological and architectural treasure by the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI).
important_figures: Muhammad Quli Qutb Shah (fifth ruler of the Qutb Shahi dynasty, builder of Charminar)
Jean de Thévenot (17th-century French traveller who documented the Charminar)
Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) (current caretaker and conservator of the monument)
applications: Functions as a religious site, housing a mosque and hosting festival celebrations (Eid-ul-adha, Eid al-Fitr).
Serves as a major tourist attraction, drawing visitors to Hyderabad.
Acts as a central hub for popular and busy local markets.
Incorporated as an official symbol in the emblem of Telangana, representing the state's heritage.
current_status: The Charminar remains a prominent historical monument and religious site in Hyderabad, actively used for prayers and festival celebrations. It is a major tourist destination, surrounded by thriving local markets, and is diligently preserved as an archaeological and architectural treasure by the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI).
future_prospects: Future prospects include continued preservation efforts by the Archaeological Survey of India to maintain its structural integrity and historical significance. It is expected to remain a vital cultural and religious landmark for the region, attracting ongoing tourism and contributing to the local economy through its surrounding markets, solidifying its status as a timeless symbol of Hyderabad.
